t: Proverbs 27
Don’t*pn boast about tomorrow, for*ln you don’t know what a day might bring.
Let*pn another praise you, and not your own mouth — a*ln stranger, and not your own lips.
A*pn stone is heavy, and sand a burden, but*ln aggravation from a fool outweighs them both.
Fury*pn is cruel, and anger a flood, but*ln who can withstand jealousy?
Better*pn an open reprimand than*ln concealed love.
The*pn wounds of a friend are trustworthy, but*ln the kisses of an enemy are excessive.
A*pn person who is full tramples on a honeycomb, but*ln to a hungry person, any bitter thing is sweet.
Anyone*pn wandering from his home is*ln like a bird wandering from its nest.
Oil*pn and incense bring joy to the heart, and*ln the sweetness of a friend is better than self-counsel.
Don’t*pn abandon your friend or your father’s friend, and*ln don’t go to your brother’s house in*ln your time of calamity; better*ln a neighbor nearby than a brother far away.
Be*pn wise, my son, and bring my heart joy, so*ln that I can answer anyone who taunts me.
A*pn sensible person sees danger and takes cover; the*ln inexperienced keep going and are punished.
Take*pn his garment, for*ln he has put up security for a stranger; get*ln collateral if it is for foreigners.
If*pn one blesses his neighbor with*ln a loud voice early in the morning, it*ln will be counted as a curse to him.
An*pn endless dripping on a rainy day and*ln a nagging wife are alike;
the*ln one who controls her controls the wind and*ln grasps oil with his right hand.
Iron*pn sharpens iron, and*ln one person sharpens another.
Whoever*pn tends a fig tree will eat its fruit, and*ln whoever looks after his master will be honored.
As*pn water reflects the face, so*ln the heart reflects the person.
Sheol*pn and Abaddon are never satisfied, and*ln people’s eyes are never satisfied.
As*pn a crucible refines silver, and*ln a smelter refines gold, so*ln a person should refine his praise.
Though*pn you grind a fool in*ln a mortar with a pestle along with grain, you*ln will not separate his foolishness from him.
Know*pn well the condition of your flock, and*ln pay attention to your herds,
for*ln wealth is not forever; not*ln even a crown lasts for all time.
When*ln hay is removed and new growth appears and*ln the grain from the hills is gathered in,
lambs*ln will provide your clothing, and*ln goats, the price of a field;
there*ln will be enough goat’s milk for your food — food*ln for your household and*ln nourishment for your female servants.
